title-group.article-title: Younger Cosmetology Workers and Environmental and Occupational Asthma Triggers at Training Sites and in Salons

contrib-group.aff: Center for School and Community-Based Research and Education and NJ Safe Schools Program, New Brunswick, New Jersey (DGS, AEMM, SWK)
Department of Environmental and Occupational Health, University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey School of Public Health, Piscataway, New Jersey (DGS, AEMM)

Environmental and Occupational Health Science Institute, University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey School of Public Health Robert Wood Johnson Medical School and Rutgers University, Piscataway, New Jersey (DGS)

author-notes.corresp: Derek G. Shendell, DEnv, MPH, Department of Environmental and Occupational Health, UMDNJ-School of Public Health, 683 Hoes Lane West, 3rd Floor, PO Box 9, Piscataway, NJ 08854; e-mail: shendedg@umdnj.edu.

abstract.p: Secondary school students in career, technical, and vocational education (CTE) programs include minors aged ≤17 years. These students enter the workforce starting at age 18 as young adults, and specifically in cosmetology after completing the State of New Jersey mandated 2-part licensing exam (theory and practical). The New Jersey Safe Schools Task Force 2010-2012 focused on potential safety and health (S&H) risks encountered by minors training in cosmetology. We conducted a stakeholder-driven participatory process with relevant state and federal agencies, private sector partners, teachers, administrators, and students from 1-in-3 of 21 county CTE school districts. We developed and disseminated Web pages (http://www.njsafeschools.org/Cosmetology.htm) with science-based information, materials such as “Right to Know” brochures in multiple languages (English, Spanish), and student-designed educational posters. Resources highlight S&H issues such as chemical exposures, including known environmental and occupational asthma triggers and respiratory irritants, for example, formaldehyde and volatile organic compounds. Asthma education professionals working in clinical management of chronic respiratory diseases can increase self-awareness of S&H in cosmetology. They can then help inform younger patients/workers with asthma, teachers, older employees, and managers/owners of hair, nail, and skin care salons of potential asthma triggers. The goal is to minimize exposures (S&H risks) among these professionals and their clients (general public).

body.p: Recent US Department of Labor–Bureau of Labor Statistics employment figures and projections into the next decade (2006-2016 to 2008-2018) indicate that a large and growing percentage of young adult workers have entered the cosmetology field.1,2 Secondary school students at least 17 years of age who are pursuing cosmetology in New Jersey need to complete a 1000-hour curriculum before taking a 2-part certification exam—with practical and theoretical components—on or after their 18th birthday, prior to obtaining employment in the field. However, the occupational safety and health (S&H) training students receive is presently focused mostly on first aid, blood-borne pathogen–related issues, and proper handling, storage, and disposal of products (hazardous chemicals). Training can be improved regarding potential ergonomic factors3,4 and exposures. Chemical exposures of concern are airborne volatile and semivolatile organic compounds known or suspected as environmental and/or occupational asthma triggers.

sec.title: Brief Review of Topic
sec.p: Hairdressers, barbers, nail technicians, and aestheticians (skin care) work daily with a wide variety of toxic chemicals. Exposure to chemicals occurs largely by inhalation as well as dermal routes; however, consequences of chronic exposure to chemical toxicants in hair and nail preparations may go beyond the airways, lungs, eyes, and skin. Adverse health effects may include contact dermatitis, occupational asthma, and/or exacerbation of symptoms among those already diagnosed with allergies and asthma. These exposures and outcomes are briefly described with more detail and specific references below. Other previous research not included herein has pertained to neurological, reproductive, and cancer-related outcomes.

Contact dermatitis, both allergic5 and irritant,6 appears to be the most common adverse health effect experienced by salon professionals due to occupational exposure. Dermatitis has been documented via exposure to dyes, varnishes, and soap and cleaning products containing known fragrance allergens.7-10 Rashes and burns from heat and chemical exposures including hydrogen peroxide11 and monoterpenes12 have been reported. In addition, eye irritation and headaches have been reported.13 Gloves appear to help prevent dermatitis among workers;4 however, gloves do not completely remove the risk of contact dermatitis, and not every type of glove offers equal amounts of protection against toxic substances.14,15 Preventing or minimizing exposure via source substitution is warranted, especially because many volatile organic chemical compounds (VOCs) are known to irritate airways and, for sensitive and allergic individuals, trigger symptoms of asthma and allergies.

Therefore, salon workers may also experience adverse health outcomes related to inhaling chemical vapors. One nail salon study suggested indoor air quality (IAQ) was generally poor.4 Salon IAQ concerns included higher levels of VOCs,16 which can be increased due to drying processes,17 though local exhaust ventilation systems reduced VOC concentrations.18 VOCs detected in air samples taken from hair, nail, and beauty salons included acetone, toluene, and propellants;19 ketones;16 isopropanol;20,21 ethanol;22 monoterpenes, such as α- and β-pinene and d-limonene;23 and ammonia, hydrogen peroxide, and persulfates.24 Salons regularly dying hair tended to have higher indoor air concentrations of phenylenediamines.25 Other salon chemical IAQ concerns included VOCs such as chloroform, benzene, and ethylene, although workers may also experience exposure to VOCs from sources both inside and outside salons.26

As a result, occupational asthma is a valid concern, especially among hairdressers27 using bleaching products.28 Asthma symptoms may also be more frequent and severe among experienced hairdressers previously exposed to vinyl chloride propellant.29 Relatively high rates of immunoglobulin E synthesis observed suggested allergy-triggered occupational asthma among hairdressers.30 Furthermore, nail technicians are at an increased risk for asthma and other respiratory symptom exacerbations, particularly those applying artificial nails with glue31 and filing nails. Allergy symptoms were even common among salon professionals who never developed asthma,22,32 including rhinitis and sinusitis.33,34 Finally, declines in lung function were observed among apprentice hairdressers.35 It must also be stated, even if previous research focused on workers, that this current body of scientific evidence from environmental science, epidemiology, and occupational health/medicine suggested salon clients from the general public, who may also have asthma and/or allergies, are clearly at potential risk of adverse acute and/or chronic health effects if exposed to the same VOCs, particularly known asthma triggers.

The New Jersey Safe Schools Task Force 2010-2012 (TF) focused on potential S&H risks encountered by 2 groups. First, minors in training as secondary school students in school-sponsored structured learning experiences36 in career, technical, and vocational education (voc-tech). Second, educated women and men as young adults entering the workforce following the state of New Jersey mandated 2-part cosmetology licensing exam (theory and practical). The first year of the TF was dedicated to meetings and focus groups with various stakeholders statewide, that is, relevant state and federal agencies, private sector partners, teachers, administrators, and students from 1-in-3 of the 21 county voc-tech school districts. In the final 2 years of the TF, one goal—based on 2 of the 20 recommendations in the first TF report in fall 2010—was to improve S&H training received by cosmetology students. Specifically, one focus was on potential inhalation exposures to chemical constituents of products frequently used and/or sold (“Right to Know” [RTK]). Through our stakeholder-driven participatory process, we developed and disseminated, for use in-person and/or online, Web pages (http://www.njsafeschools.org/Cosmetology.htm) with science-based information, “RTK” brochures in multiple languages (English and Spanish), and student-designed educational posters. The Web pages also provide direct links to other state and federal agency resources, and university-based program resources, pertinent to cosmetology and/or chemical S&H, that is, RTK. The brochures and posters highlighted S&H issues related to ergonomics and chemical exposures including environmental and occupational asthma triggers.

Table 1 summarizes, based on current peer-reviewed literature, the most pertinent chemicals of concern with respect to allergy and asthma for younger and older adults working in or being served in nail, hair, and skin care salons.4,7,11,14,15,18,24,32,34,37-44 Table 1 lists products in which these specific chemicals are found in salons (and in specialty stores) as well as known adverse human health effects due to acute and/or chronic exposure (inhalation and/or dermal) in the workplace. Table 1 and the aforementioned TF Web pages and brochures were based on a comprehensive literature review conducted as part of TF activities of the New Jersey Safe Schools staff in 2010-2011.

caption.p: Summary of Chemical Agents and Corresponding Adverse Respiratory Related Adverse Health Effects From Cosmetology Products4,7,11,14,15,18,24,32,34,37-44

tr.th: Products in Which Chemicals Are Found

tr.td: Skin, eye, nose, and throat irritation; coughing and wheezing
Permanent hair color, permanent wave preparations

Can severely irritate and burn skin and eyes with possible eye damage; nose and throat irritation with coughing and wheezing; can irritate lungs causing difficulty when breathing; higher exposures can cause fluid buildup in lungs; repeated exposure can lead to an asthma-like allergic response; can cause permanent lung damage
Skin, eye, nose, and throat irritation

Contact can severely irritate and burn skin and eyes, with permanent eye damage possible; irritation of eyes, nose, throat, mouth, and lungs causing coughing and shortness of breath with pulmonary edema possible
Nail polish, nail polish remover, fingernail glue
Can irritate skin, eyes, nose, and throat
Brazilian style keratin-based hair treatments, nail polish, nail hardener

Contact can severely irritate and burn skin and eyes, including delayed burns, with permanent eye damage possible; irritation of eyes, nose, throat, mouth, and lungs causing coughing and shortness of breath with pulmonary edema possible; repeated exposure can cause bronchitis and asthma-like allergy; skin allergy
May cause contact allergy, irritant dermatitis—mostly on hands; occupational asthma and rhinitis
Permanent wave preparations, permanent hair color, hair bleaches

Contact can severely irritate and burn skin and eyes with possible eye damage; nose and throat irritation; lung irritation causing coughing and shortness of breath with possible pulmonary edema; can irritate lungs and cause bronchitis
Skin, eye, nose, and throat irritation; coughing and wheezing

sec.title: Conclusion and Importance to Asthma Educators
sec.p: Enhanced knowledge, skills, and awareness (KSA) of these S&H issues among professionals involved in asthma education and the clinical and behavior management of chronic respiratory diseases and allergies can help reduce potential indoor exposures. In general, fewer exposures mean decreased risk of associated health effects due to poor IAQ. Poor IAQ at hair, nail, and skin care salons can result from improper use of products individually or in mixtures (eg, inaccurate concentrations) and/or inadequate ventilation. Increasing KSAs of asthma triggers in cosmetology could potentially lead to a network of health and education professionals and salon workers with enhanced training. They would help protect susceptible, vulnerable populations from hazardous exposure agents in salons. Specifically, for example, they would be able to share information and direct coworkers and clients to online resources like the New Jersey Safe Schools Cosmetology/RTK Web site pages and linked federal and state agency Web sites. Clients seeking hair styling, hair cutting, and nail salon services and workers providing these services can be better positioned than individual programs to influence public health among the rapidly growing career area/cluster of cosmetology. Given the diverse populations living in communities throughout the United States, this strategy could also facilitate the distribution of appropriate information to numerous ethnic groups, in multiple languages, on reducing exposure to salon chemicals known to be asthma and allergy triggers and irritants.

ack.p: We thank the New Jersey (NJ) Department of Education (NJDOE), Office of Career and Technical Education, for funding the NJ Safe Schools Program (NJ SS). We acknowledge efforts of NJ SS staff for their efforts on behalf of education and public agency professionals throughout NJ. We thank NJ Occupational Safety and Health Alliance members representing multiple federal and state agencies and institutions for supporting NJ SS.
